text: Family Member: Maybe put that down so you can focus some again on the radium study. Doctor: So I, I was going to talk to you about a radioactive thing we have that’s very specifically targeted the prostate cancer cells. Uh, I keep telling folks about it, and then it keeps taking too long, and we haven’t opened the trial yet. I thought we were going to open it in August. It’s now December. Family Member: What’s the name of it? Patient: Radium. Doctor: Well, no, the radium’s a different thing. So the radium, uh, this is called, this is just, it’s P-S-M-A, targeted, uh. Family Member: But it hasn’t gotten here yet? They looking at it in kind of-? Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct. Patient: - seminal vesicles and (patient talking over doctor) Doctor: So when we talk about side effects there’s always the potential – Patient: Right. text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more Patient: Okay. Doctor: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so we’d have to check with your insurance. Do they cover clinical trials, if you’re interested? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, if they are. Then in the forms that we give them and give you, it tells them, huh, what they’re paying for, and it tells you what we’re going to pay for. So definitely the dummy vitamin C or the real vitamin C we pay for because that’s experimental. Your insurance company may have to pay for the time in the chair to get the medicine. Okay? Huh, if you have to pay five dollars every time you come into this building, huh, this study could cost you more money because you’re here more often. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, but if you don’t have a copay for visits, then that’s, you know. So there are some hidden costs. You know? If you’re coming in more often and you have to pay for parking and, you know, those sorts of things, huh, we do have the ability for some of our studies to pay for your parking. We do. Or even if you need a ride here, there’s a group of, do you live in the city? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. We definitely have a program to help city residents if they have trouble getting in that often. Huh, huh, you know, the chemotherapy is going to cause hair loss. Huh, seventy-five percent of the time you lose your hair, it grows back. Huh, you might get excess tearing because it can block the tear ducts. So a little bit. The other reason why we might want to wait a little bit is just to see how much your palsy is going to get better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, it drops blood counts. So right now your white count’s good. Your platelets are good. Huh, but we may need to give you a blood transfusion if we make you more anemic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, huh, we can drop your blood count, white count, and so you might get a higher risk of infection. Huh, usually we know about that. We tell you to be careful. Sometimes we give you antibiotics. And if it happens every time, sometimes we’re going to give you a medicine that’s going to bring up your white count so it doesn’t drop. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point. Patient: Okay do you think… Doctor: Because we’ll really have exhausted that Xtandi is not working definitely before we decide to switch to Lynparza at that point. Patient: How soon will you know? I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
